title: Yasuo already has a meaningful presence in every elo and isn't in any way struggling
body:
Yet Riot wants to buff him.

> Magic Resist increased from 30 to 32.1

An interesting idea. Let's look at some numbers to see if that's true. For the sake of this comparison, we'll look at {{champion:39}} vs. {{champion:157}} since both are melee champs with no other defensive steroids.

Base AD: Irelia 61.5-118, Yasuo 55.5-110

Base HP: Irelia 607-2137, Yasuo 518, 1912

Base Armor: Irelia 25.3-89, Yasuo 24.7-82.5

Base MR: Irelia 32.1-53.4, Yasuo 30-38.5

Base AS: Irelia .665-54.5%, Yasuo .670-42.5% 

Base Health Regen: Irelia 8.59-19.6, Yasuo 6.51-21.8

At lvl 1, Irelia had 5 more AD, 89 more health, .5 more armor, 2 more MR, 2 per 5 health regen, and about equal attack speed. That's an extra 117+237+10+36=400 gold worth of extra stats at lvl 1 without accounting for the health regen which has variable value depending on what champ you're playing. Yasuo by comparison has a 100 shield at lvl 1 that lasts for 1 second and procs whenever his flow is full whether he wants it to or not. It's hard to say how much gold value this is actually worth since it's highly dependent on his opponent but it is very rare that Yasuo gets the full value out of his shield, especially against ranged champions. Even if we're generous and count at it the full 100 health value, that's still only an extra 267 gold in stats, a full 133 less than what Irelia gets. Keep in mind that Irelia also has free sustain on her W while Yasuo does not, further growing the effective stats lead.

Still want the shield instead? I'll happily trade you.

You also assume the shield gets procced the instant it comes up every single time and also always absorbs the full value. Both assumptions are obviously wrong. The shield value is also silly because the average champion at 20 minutes is around lvl 10-13, not lvl 18. A Yasuo in a 20 minute game would have the vast majority of his shields at below 200, let alone an average of 275 like you claim. Theorycrafting like this is based on so many absurd assumptions that it's worthless. Hell, what I was doing isn't even theorycrafting but rather a straight analysis comparing Irelia's and Yasuo's stats at lvl 1. Irelia clearly has a huge edge even if the shield is used to its full potential which is rarely is. Yasuo's shield is meant to give him windows of power and weakness in lane which, given his extremely high level of agency around minions, is to the benefit of his opponent, not him. If Yasuo had the base stats to beat people whenever minions were around, he'd be completely insufferable to lane against. As it stands, he's tolerable unless your champion is absolutely horrible against Yasuo 1v1.

I've argued this countless times, so I'm just gonna make some points:

1.-I'm talking about statistical 1v1 scenarios, most champions can win 2v1, and the win rates measurements cover for that (so saying "they win if their jungler helps them" is not a valid argument because the opposite could be said of Yasuo).

2.-If you look at actual win rates, you will see that out of all those champs you mentioned only annie, kayle (who is not a mage mind you) and anivia actually beat Yasuo conclusively. Ekko, Heimer and Lissandra go toe to toe. All the other champions lose game currently if you look at the statistics, regardless of all the scenarios you want to describe (just go look at the win rates, trimming to identify lane phase.

3.- What you fail to take into account is that early game Yasuo dominates most champs you have listed, because of a number of factors:

* Being AD, yasuo can push towers faster than most mages, and starting with dorans blade or shield plus his  passive shield and life steal give yasuo more sustain over most mages, which run out of mana trying to push back

* Yasuo has more damage over time (dps) early game because he is AD and his autos are worth more. With his great mobility, most mages have to play very passively, because if they over step Yasuo can out trade them and then sustain back up with life steal, while mages have to use mana to push back

* Between level 3 and 6, if a mage makes a mistake in their positioning, then Yasuo can punish them really hard. In contrast, if Yasuo makes a positioning mistake then he has his shield and wind wall to back him up.

* Because most mages don't have much damage early game, every spell they miss is very costly because they have to use mana and run out of it. Yasuo can easily dodge spells with his e and W, while his own e, autos and close range Q are nearly impossible to miss
